710632f-a.text: 11th Avenue, north north from W 34th street showing this thoroughfare prior to the removal of railroad equipment and its general rehabilitation. At the left, occupying the 34th to 35th street frontage, is the distinctive former Manhattan Market shed (erected 1871). This was razed in several stages, years apart. First the original 3-story structure was reduced to the one story building shown, and subsequently the Avenue frontage was cleared. The final stage occurred in 1946 when the sheds on the street sides were removed. View 3 shows the 34th Street side prior to the same. February 7 1932

710633f-a.text:
11th Avenue, north from W. 34th Street, showing prominently the westerly side of this thoroughfare. At the left, occupyinr the 34th to 35th Street frontage is the former Manhattan Market of 1871. This has been reduced to a one story building in View 1 and partially removed in View 2. The street sides will come down in 1938 and thereby
clear the entire block.
In the midground are buildings at 36th Street. The larrest is the V'lliams Printing House. This occupies the 36th to 37th Street frontage and will remain; those to its rear being removed in May 1938. Note the towering R. H. Macy and Company warehouse on the right. The 1ower stbeies are being reconstructed to permit an underground railway to Dass through its basement n its way under 1lth Avenue.
August 11, 1934
August 12, 1936
P. L. Sperr

710633f-b.text:

clear the entire block.
In the midground are buildings at 36th Street. The larrest is the V'lliams Printing House. This occupies the 36th to 37th Street frontage and will remain; those to its rear being removed in May 1938. Note the towering R. H. Macy and Company warehouse on the right. The 1ower stbeies are being reconstructed to permit an underground railway to Dass through its basement n its way under 1lth Avenue.
August 11, 1934
August 12, 1936
P. L. Sperr

710634f-a.text:
11th Avenue, west side, from W. 34th to 35th Streets, showing the old Manhattan Market of 1871 in three distinct stares. The original structure appears in View 1. View 2 shows same lowered to one story. View 3 is a frontal view after demolition of Avenue building. The street sides shown and extending to 12th Avenue, will be razed
in 1938 and thereby clearing the entire block.
May 17, 1927
Februay 7, 1932
May 1, 1937
P. L. Sperr

710636f-a.text:
LDleventh Ave. (foreground), from West 34th (right), to 36th (left) Streets, showing work in progress for the New York Central Railroad's track removal project as a part of the West Side Improvement, viewed in a southeastward direction from the latter point and westward of the Avenue. At the left foreground is a part of the old Eleventh Ave. grade, over which the railroad operated for Eighty-eight years. Note that the present Avenue is elevated about ten feet and about one-third of this extension being shown in this view; the new yard tracks passing underneath same and connecting the southern two and one-half mile stretch with the rock cut bed. Undergoing remodeling is the old R.H. Macy warehouse at
the N.E. corner of the Avenue and VWest 25th Street.
July 244, 1937.
Gift of New Vork Central System.
Publicity Bureau.

710638f-a.text:
Hleventh Ave. (elevated streetbed across the center from the right margin to the left) from West 34th (right) to 37th (left) Streets, as viewed eastward from a point in the New York Central Railroad yards on the west side of the Avenue and on a line with 35th Street,to show the tracks descending from the loop viaduct around the yard,connecting with the trackage in the rock cut coming out from under Eleventh Avenue and the old R.H. Macy warehouse. Shortly after the zero house, Eight A.k., Sunday June 27, 1937, the small bridge carrying Eleventh AVenue ower the hole where the tracks pass through, will be lifted out by power cranes, the track cut over and the second major stage of the West Side Inprovement Project put in service.
June 25, 1937.
00ift of New york Central System
Publicity Bureau.

710639f-a.text:
(1)
Eleventh Ave., east side, north from and including West 34th Street. Prominent building shown, at the N.E. corner of 35th Street, with its sub-structure altered to permit the passage of railroad trains as a part
of the west side track removal programm.
May 1, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same; at a later date, and showing the lower floors of Macy's
12-story loft building being exposed.
August 12, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same as No. 2. Note the freight trains on Eleventh Ave.
Eventually these will run under ground.
August 12, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

710642f-a.text:
Eleventh Ave. (center, fore to background), south from West 35th Street, showing constructional aspects of the track removal program of the New York Central Railroad as their portion of the West Side Tmprovement Project. The photographer's vantage point iw the former R.H. Macy warehouse at 35th Street and he showw about one-third of the Eleventh Ave. stretch and one-half of the 34th Street stretch elevated to their new levels. This will be continued southward on the Avenue for an additional 5 blocks and the yard tracks that now cross it at grade will be rebuilt several feet below their present grade and on a radically different pattern. Note on the extreme right top a vista of
the North (Rudson) River.
June 25, 1937.
Gift of New York Central System
Publioity Bureau.
